Title: Zhong Restaurant (钟餐厅) – Gulou West Street Branch
Description:
📍 Address: No. 37 Gulou West Street, Xicheng District, Beijing
🕒 Hours: Daily, 10:30 AM–2:30 PM & 4:30 PM–10:00 PM
💰 Price Range: ¥150–180 per person
🌐 Cuisine: Huaiyang (Jiangsu-style), refined southern Chinese dishes

🍽️ What Makes It Special?
Zhong Restaurant is a tiny hutong gem run by Chef Zhong, known for his background in fine dining. Instead of grand luxury, he offers elevated Huaiyang dishes in a cozy 7-table courtyard setting. It’s an ideal mix of authentic regional cuisine and neighborhood charm—no-frills, just food made with care.

In 2023, it earned a Bib Gourmand from the Michelin Guide, recognizing its high quality and value.

🍜 Recommended Dishes
Yang Chun Noodles (阳春面): A delicate broth noodle with subtle sweetness—Huaiyang simplicity at its best.

Xiang You Shan Hu (响油鳝糊): Fragrant stir-fried eel with sizzling soy sauce; rich yet balanced.

Marinated Cold Platter (糟卤拼盘): Includes abalone, duck tongue, and prawns steeped in rice wine lees.

Braised Pork Soup (腌笃鲜): A comforting soup of pork and bamboo shoots, slow-cooked to perfection.

Seasonal sides & homemade pickles: Ask the chef for what’s fresh.

🪑 Ambience & Experience
Tiny but tasteful: Only 7 tables in a traditional Beijing hutong.

Chef-hosted experience: Chef Zhong personally cooks and serves, making it feel like dining in someone’s home.

Simple, wood-paneled interior: Minimalist elegance in a small space.

Quiet location: Just west of the Drum Tower, easy to miss—part of the charm.

🎯 Why It’s Worth a Visit
If you’re looking for a restaurant that combines Michelin-approved flavor, deep local character, and a peaceful dining atmosphere, Zhong is your place. It’s not touristy, not flashy—but quietly exceptional. A truly rare find in Beijing’s bustling food scene.
Tips:
📋 Menu Language	Chinese only — use translation apps or photos to point
🗣️ Communication	Limited English, but staff are kind and used to foreign guests
💳 Payment	WeChat Pay, Alipay, and usually cash accepted
💰 Price Range: ¥150–180 per person
⏰ Best visit time	10:30 AM sharp for lunch / 4:30 PM for dinner to avoid long waits
❌ No reservations	Walk-in only, arrive early to secure a table
🚇 Nearest subway	Line 8 or Line 6 – Gulou Dajie Station (10 min walk)

Title: Yishan Noodle House 壹山面店 (鼓楼店)
Description:
🥢 Yishan Noodle House 壹山面店 (鼓楼店)

📍 Address: No. 20 Zhaofu Street (near Gulou East Street), Dongcheng, Beijing – close to Gulou East and Beixinqiao area 

🕒 Opening Hours: Typically around 11:00 AM–9:00 PM; please check local listings as hours may vary 
💰 Price Range: Around ¥45 per person—mid‑range for Shanxi-style noodle house 

🍜 Cuisine & Highlights
Authentic Shanxi noodles (山西菜): A must-visit for lovers of Shanxi cuisine; it ranked top 8 on Beijing’s Shanxi restaurants list 

Recommended dishes:
Guo You Rou Ban Mian (过油肉拌面) – noodles tossed with crispy fried pork slices
Dui Jiao You Gao (泡泡油糕) – light, fried dough snacks
Gansi Rou Mian (尖椒肉丝面) – pepper pork shreds with noodles 
Simple, warm décor: Wooden stools, open kitchen, casual yet modern rustic vibe (see carousel)

💡 Dining Tips for Travelers
Go off-peak: Visit during late lunch or early evening to avoid crowds; waits possible during peak Gulou hours.

Ideal for solo or pair meals: Generous noodle bowls let you enjoy a full meal without ordering multiple dishes.

No English menu: Order by photo/menu or ask “哪道面好吃?” (“Which noodles are good?”); staff are accustomed to tourists in the area.

Mobile payment accepted: Alipay & WeChat Pay work; cash may also be welcomed.

🎯 Why Visit Yishan Noodle House?
Located in the historic Gulou neighborhood, Yishan brings hearty Shanxi noodle flavors to travelers looking for authentic, unpretentious local food. With comforting bowls like pork-tossed noodles and fried snacks, it’s a perfect casual stop before or after exploring the Drum Tower, Hutongs, or nearby breakfast spots like Yaoji Chaogan.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: Typically around 11:00 AM–9:00 PM; please check local listings as hours may vary 
💰 Price Range: Around ¥45 per person—mid‑range for Shanxi-style noodle house 
Go off-peak: Visit during late lunch or early evening to avoid crowds; waits possible during peak Gulou hours.

Ideal for solo or pair meals: Generous noodle bowls let you enjoy a full meal without ordering multiple dishes.

No English menu: Order by photo/menu or ask “哪道面好吃?” (“Which noodles are good?”); staff are accustomed to tourists in the area.

Mobile payment accepted: Alipay & WeChat Pay work; cash may also be welcomed.

Title: Ding Xiang Run 鼎香润 — Deshengmen Inner St Branch
Description:
🍜 Ding Xiang Run 鼎香润 — Deshengmen Inner St Branch

📍 Address: No. 34–36 Deshengmen Inner Street, Xicheng District, Beijing (near Shichahai) 

🕒 Hours: Daily, 11 AM–3 PM & 5 PM–11 PM 
💳 Price: Average ~¥60–80 per person—excellent value for hearty Beijing fare 


🌟 Highlights & Signature Dishes
“Lazy Dragon” (懒龙): A hand-sized rolled pancake stuffed with generous meat filling—the golden star of the menu. Crispy exterior, succulent interior—locals describe it as "full of familiar family taste" 
Braised Pork Hock (招牌肘子): Melt-in-your-mouth tender, neither greasy nor dry, prepared the traditional way
Traditional “Explosive Trio” (爆三样): A bold stir-fry of pork slices, intestines, and liver—rich, flavorful, and decidedly Beijing-style
Sweet & Sour Ribs & Kung Pao Chicken: Crispy, balanced, and crowd-pleasing staples
Dry-fried Intestines, Qianlong Cabbage: Classics among many options captured in diners' photos

🍲 Why It’s a Must-Visit
Down-to-earth Beijing flavors in a relaxed, retro-style setting—ideal for travelers seeking authentic local cuisine without the fuss.

Standout dishes like Lazy Dragon and braised hock offer a memorable taste experience for adventurous eaters.

Fantastic value: hearty dishes, large portions, and budget-friendly prices (~¥68 per person) 

Prime location: steps away from Shichahai lake—perfect to combine with a stroll and sightseeing.

💡 Dining Tips for Visitors
Go early (just after 11 AM) or later in the evening (~5 PM) to avoid peak-time crowds and ensure top dishes are available.

Order family-style: Share 3–4 dishes (Lazy Dragon, braised hock, ribs, stir-fry) among 2–3 people for a fulfilling meal.

Language ease: Menu in Chinese only; pointing at dishes or using translation apps works well.

Payment & setup: Cashless options like WeChat Pay are accepted; seating is casual with communal and window tables overlooking charming hutong streets.

🎯 In Summary…
Ding Xiang Run is a beloved neighborhood gem offering classic Beijing soul food in a friendly, unassuming setting. Come for the Lazy Dragon and stay for the hock, stir-fries, and cheery atmosphere—it’s a delicious window into local life near beautiful Shichahai.
Tips:
🕒 Hours: Daily, 11 AM–3 PM & 5 PM–11 PM 
💳 Price: Average ~¥60–80 per person—excellent value for hearty Beijing fare 
Go early (just after 11 AM) or later in the evening (~5 PM) to avoid peak-time crowds and ensure top dishes are available.

Order family-style: Share 3–4 dishes (Lazy Dragon, braised hock, ribs, stir-fry) among 2–3 people for a fulfilling meal.

Language ease: Menu in Chinese only; pointing at dishes or using translation apps works well.

Payment & setup: Cashless options like WeChat Pay are accepted; seating is casual with communal and window tables overlooking charming hutong streets.

Title: Fumanyuan (福满园) – Xinyuan South Road Branch
Description:
📍 Address: No. 10 Xinyuan South Road, Chaoyang District, Beijing (世方豪庭 opposite) 

🕒 Opening Hours: Daily from 11:00 AM to 10:00 PM 
💳 Price Range: Approximately ¥80–100 per person, excellent value for hearty Beijing-style home cooking 

🌟 What to Try (must-order dishes)
Red-braised Hairtail (红烧带鱼): Incredibly tender, flavorful, so melt-in-your-mouth that even the bones are edible; fans rave you should “go all-in” 
Fish Roe Braised Tofu (鱼籽烧豆腐): Rich and savory “rice-bowl hero” designed for maximum pleasure 
Sour‑Spicy Shredded Potatoes (酸辣土豆丝): A surprise crowd favorite—refreshingly crisp with just the right tang 
Egg-Battered Mantou Slices (鸡蛋馒头片): Nostalgic street-flavor comfort food, best enjoyed warm and crisp 
Braised Pork Ribs & Green Beans (排骨炖豆角): Tender, well-seasoned, another classic that keeps locals coming back 

🏠 Ambience & Experience
Cozy, bustling family-style eatery: Compact but always lively—lunch rushes can have queues and even shared tables. It's said to feel like your "second cafeteria" 

Traditional décor: Simple interior with old-school Chinese charm, including “福” (blessing) characters, wall murals, and communal tables 

Cashless payment-friendly: Accepts mobile payments alongside cards, despite its old‑school heart 

💡 Dining Tips
Arrive early or join the queue: Peak lunch or early evening sees wait times; go just before 11:30 AM or around 5 PM for quicker seating.

Share multiple dishes: Ideal for groups—order 3–5 dishes to experience a taste of everything.

Perfect combo: Try fish + tofu + mantou slices for a full-on comforting meal.

Parking & transit: Street parking is limited; best accessed via taxi or rideshare.

Bring your camera: A trip to Fumanyuan is an authentic peek into local life—photo-worthy scenes abound.

🎯 Why Overseas Guests Should Go

Fumanyuan delivers classic Beijing comfort food in a lively, down-to-earth setting loved by locals. The star dishes offer flavors rooted in daily life, cooked exactly how Beijingers grew up eating. Whether you're visiting a Michelin-Plate dining experience or a fine-dining venue, Fumanyuan sits at the heart of urban authenticity—a true taste of contemporary Beijing culture.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: Daily from 11:00 AM to 10:00 PM 
💳 Price Range: Approximately ¥80–100 per person, excellent value for hearty Beijing-style home cooking 
Arrive early or join the queue: Peak lunch or early evening sees wait times; go just before 11:30 AM or around 5 PM for quicker seating.

Share multiple dishes: Ideal for groups—order 3–5 dishes to experience a taste of everything.

Perfect combo: Try fish + tofu + mantou slices for a full-on comforting meal.

Parking & transit: Street parking is limited; best accessed via taxi or rideshare.

Bring your camera: A trip to Fumanyuan is an authentic peek into local life—photo-worthy scenes abound.

Title: Dongsi Minfang Restaurant 东四民芳餐厅 (Chaoyangmen)
Description:
🍲 Dongsi Minfang Restaurant 东四民芳餐厅 (Chaoyangmen)

📍 Address (Chaoyangmen main branch): No. 79‑2 Chaoyangmen Inner Street (朝阳门内大街79‑2号), Dongcheng District, Beijing – just northwest of Chaoyangmen Station (Lines 2 & 6) 

🕒 Opening Hours: Daily ~10:30 AM–10:00 PM (some sources say until 10:30 PM) 
💰 Price Range: Approximately ¥100–112 per person 
🍽 Cuisine: Cozy, home-style Beijing dishes—part of the city's beloved modern “Eight Great Ju” eateries.

🌟 Signature Dishes You Should Try
Fish Head with Pancakes (鱼头泡饼): a hearty, tangy soup loaded with shredded bread – a local favorite 
Sesame‑sauce Sweet Pancakes (芝麻酱糖饼): sweet and nutty, crispy and soothingly familiar 
Stir‑fried Meatballs (焦溜丸子): crisp outside, tender inside—a must-try Beijing classic 
Kung Pao Chicken (宫保鸡丁): refreshingly updated with delicate Beijing flavors 
Peking Duck (精品烤鸭): crispy-skinned and succulent, served in a local-style presentation 
Other favorites: Sweet and sour ribs, stir-fried intestines, braised ribbonfish, marinated elbow meat 

🏡 Ambience & Local Vibes
Casual and bustling: Unpretentious interior with friendly service and quick table turnover—great for daily meals or family-style dining 

Busy at peak times: Evenings can fill up—easy to book a private room via phone; tour guides use SMS reminders 

Trusted legacy: Established in 1985 by Zhao Min & Zhou Fang—“Minfang” (民芳) highlights its commitment to comforting, home-cooked flavors 

💡 Practical Tips for Visitors
Go early or reserve: Popular at dinner—reserve a private room 3–4 days ahead, or show up before 6 PM 

Good for sharing: Dishes are generous in size—order 3–5 plates to share amongst 2–4 people

English: pointing works fine: No formal English menu, but staff are accustomed to tourists; menus with visuals are helpful 

Located by subway: A short walk from Chaoyangmen Station (NW exit) and one block from Dongsi crossroads 

Payment: Accepts cash and credit cards; free Wi-Fi and parking available 

🎯 Why It’s Perfect for Overseas Visitors

Dongsi Minfang is an accessible gateway into everyday Beijing cuisine—without the fanfare. With well-executed classics like fish head soup, sesame pancakes, and meatballs, it offers a taste of local life. The atmosphere is lively and familiar—a place where locals dine and tourists are welcomed warmly.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: Daily ~10:30 AM–10:00 PM (some sources say until 10:30 PM) 
💰 Price Range: Approximately ¥100–112 per person 
Go early or reserve: Popular at dinner—reserve a private room 3–4 days ahead, or show up before 6 PM 

Good for sharing: Dishes are generous in size—order 3–5 plates to share amongst 2–4 people

English: pointing works fine: No formal English menu, but staff are accustomed to tourists; menus with visuals are helpful 

Payment: Accepts cash and credit cards; free Wi-Fi and parking available

Title: Dongxing Lou Restaurant (东兴楼饭庄) – Dongzhimen Branch
Description:
🥢 Dongxing Lou Restaurant (东兴楼饭庄) – Dongzhimen Branch

📍 Address: No. 5 Dongzhimen Inner Street, Xicheng District, Beijing (just off Guijie, steps from Dongzhimen Station – Lines 2/13/Airport Line) 
🕒 Opening Hours: Daily ~10:30 AM–9:30 PM 
🍽 Cuisine: Classic Shandong (Lu) cuisine—one of Beijing’s legendary “Eight Great Lou” roots back to 1902 

🌟 Highlights & Signature Dishes
Scallion-Braised Sea Cucumber (葱烧海参) & U-fish Roe Soup (烩乌鱼蛋汤): iconic dishes praised for richness and depth 
Explosive Trio (爆三样): spicy stir-fry with pork slices, intestines, and liver—a local favorite 
New-style Fried meatballs (干炸小丸子) & Sweet & sour crayfish (油焖大虾): crispy, tender, and flavorful stars of the menu 
Kazao Fish Fillet (糟溜鱼片) & Saucy Chicken Cubes (酱爆鸡丁): traditional Lu tastes with modern finesse 

🏛 Heritage & Ambience
Established in the Guangxu era (1902) as a prestigious courtyard-style eatery, Dongxing Lou was revived in Dongzhimen in the early 1980s, reuniting its original chefs and heritage signage to reclaim its former glory 

Today it remains a top-rated Lu cuisine destination, praised for preserving both tradition and quality 

The restaurant features a spacious, heritage-inspired interior with ground-level open seating and private upstairs rooms—perfect for small groups or family dinners 

💡 Tips for Visitors
Arrive early around opening time (~10:30 AM) to avoid crowds and ensure your favorite dishes are available 

Order family-style – shareable dishes like sea cucumber, trio stir-fry, fried meatballs, and crayfish give you a panoramic taste of Lu culinary style.

Don’t miss the soups – rich broths like U-fish Roe and sweet-and-sour soups define the restaurant’s reputation 

English support – menus may lack English, so pointing at photos or dishes works well; helpful staff and visuals guide you.

Easy transport – located right off Dongzhimen Station; parking available nearby 

💵 Price Range
Expect ¥115–162 per person, offering generous portions and high-quality ingredients—great value for historic, hearty Beijing dining 

🎯 Why Overseas Guests Should Go
Historical significance: A flagship of Beijing’s “Eight Great Lou” and Shandong culinary heritage.

Authentic flavors: Lu cuisine dishes that balance boldness and finesse, ideal for first-timers.

Atmospheric setting: A classic courtyard ambiance near lively Guijie—great photo and cultural appeal.

Convenient location: Perfectly placed for a meal either before or after exploring Dongzhimen and surrounding nightlife.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: Daily ~10:30 AM–9:30 PM 
Arrive early around opening time (~10:30 AM) to avoid crowds and ensure your favorite dishes are available 

Order family-style – shareable dishes like sea cucumber, trio stir-fry, fried meatballs, and crayfish give you a panoramic taste of Lu culinary style.

Don’t miss the soups – rich broths like U-fish Roe and sweet-and-sour soups define the restaurant’s reputation 

English support – menus may lack English, so pointing at photos or dishes works well; helpful staff and visuals guide you.

💵 Price Range
Expect ¥115–162 per person, offering generous portions and high-quality ingredients—great value for historic, hearty Beijing dining

Title: Tianxingju (天兴居) – Xianyukou Location
Description:
🥢 Tianxingju (天兴居) – Xianyukou Location

📍 Address: 81–83 Xianyukou Street, Dongcheng District, Beijing (near Qianmen) 
🕒 Opening Hours: 7 AM–8 PM daily 
💰 Average Spend: ~¥26 per person for breakfast/light meal 

🍲 What to Try
Chǎogān (炒肝) – Beijing’s iconic pork-liver-and-intestine stew, thickened and rich but not greasy. Served in a small bowl to be sipped around the rim — a true local ritual 
Steamed buns (包子) – Especially pork-onion and savory “three-fresh” buns; diners praise their warmth and flavor 
Side items – Accompany with millet porridge, pickles, and the restaurant's refreshing plum juice. Note: porridge quality can vary .

🌟 Highlights & Heritage
A Ming–Qing era classic: Founded in 1862 as Huixianju, later renamed Tianxingju in 1933. Merged with Huixianju in 1956 to refine chǎogān recipes 

Recognized by local authorities and culinary associations for preserving authentic Beijing flavors 

💡 Tips for Overseas Visitors
Early bird recommended: Most locals enjoy Tianxingju for breakfast, and popular items like buns and chǎogān may sell out midday 

How to eat chǎogān: Hold the bowl and sip around the edge — using a spoon is a sign you're an outsider! 

Perfect pairing: Try one danwei (30g, typically 3 buns) of pork scallion buns, a bowl of chǎogān, some pickles, and plum juice — a complete local breakfast.

Language note: No English menu; photos help. Locals know this place — just point and smile.

Nearby sightseeing: Located on historic Xianyukou Street, it's easy to combine with visits to Qianmen or Dashilan and explore traditional hutong culture 

🎯 Why It's Worth Visiting
Tianxingju captures the essence of old Beijing — simple, hearty, unpretentious flavors served in a way that’s steeped in tradition. For adventurous travelers, it offers an authentic taste of local life and a morning ritual firmly rooted in the city’s culinary heritage.
Tips:
📍 Address: 81–83 Xianyukou Street, Dongcheng District, Beijing (near Qianmen) 
🕒 Opening Hours: 7 AM–8 PM daily 
💰 Average Spend: ~¥26 per person for breakfast/light meal 
Early bird recommended: Most locals enjoy Tianxingju for breakfast, and popular items like buns and chǎogān may sell out midday 

How to eat chǎogān: Hold the bowl and sip around the edge — using a spoon is a sign you're an outsider! 

Perfect pairing: Try one danwei (30g, typically 3 buns) of pork scallion buns, a bowl of chǎogān, some pickles, and plum juice — a complete local breakfast.

Language note: No English menu; photos help. Locals know this place — just point and smile.

Nearby sightseeing: Located on historic Xianyukou Street, it's easy to combine with visits to Qianmen or Dashilan and explore traditional hutong culture

Title: Bai Kui Laohao Restaurant / 白魁老号饭庄（交道口店）
Description:
🕌 Bai Kui Laohao Restaurant / 白魁老号饭庄（交道口店）

📍 Address: No. 158 Jiaodaokou South Street, Dongcheng, Beijing (东城区交道口南大街158号) 
🕒 Opening Hours: 6:00 AM–9:30 PM daily; split into breakfast/lunch/dinner sessions 
💳 Average Spend: ¥30–50 per person for snacks; full meal ~¥100–160 

🌟 Heritage & Ambience
Founded during Qing Qianlong (1780) near Longfusi Temple and later expanded under the Bai Kui name 

A century-old halal eatery featuring classic red-and-green facade and traditional décor—casual, busy, local vibe with friendly service 

Located at a bustling intersection in historic Jiaodaokou, easily navigable and a popular local hangout 

🍽 Specialty Dishes
Roast lamb (烧羊肉): Signature dish made with 24 spices, six-step process yielding tender, flavorful meat 

Lamb offal soup (羊杂汤) and sweetbread soup (羊脑花汤): hearty halal soups beloved by Beijing locals 

Snack highlights:
Mending meat patties (门钉肉饼) – crisp and delicious
Bean powder cake (豌豆糕) – subtle sweetness
Fried butter cakes (奶油炸糕), sugar rolls (糖卷果), donkey-rolling cake (驴打滚) – classic Beijing treats 
Savory stir-fries: Sautéed tripe, mu shu vegetables, stir-fried pea tofu and others 
China Highlights

💡 Dining Tips
Ideal for all-day visits: Opens early (6 AM), making it great for breakfast or any-time snacks 

Go with an appetite: Share a few snacks, a soup, and the roast lamb for a fulfilling experience.

Local flavor note: Try bean-juice (豆汁儿) – an acquired taste, aromatic and sour, it’s distinctly Beijing 

Ordering ease: Buy a queue ticket before entering. Menus may lack English, but staff are patient, and pointing/photo menus work well 

Cash & Card: Payment doesn’t require advanced prep; just bring cash or cards.

🎯 Why Overseas Visitors Should Go
Authentic heritage: One of Beijing’s oldest halal food houses with traditional Beijing snacks and lamb dishes.

Local experience: A no-frills, breakfast-to-dinner spot beloved by locals—eat like a Beijinger.

Variety & value: From snacks priced under ¥10 to stomach-warming soups and roast lamb, it’s budget-friendly and tasty.

Cultural immersion: Located in a historic neighborhood, it’s a snapshot of old Beijing life and cuisine.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: 6:00 AM–9:30 PM daily; split into breakfast/lunch/dinner sessions 
💳 Average Spend: ¥30–50 per person for snacks; full meal ~¥100–160 
Ideal for all-day visits: Opens early (6 AM), making it great for breakfast or any-time snacks 

Go with an appetite: Share a few snacks, a soup, and the roast lamb for a fulfilling experience.

Local flavor note: Try bean-juice (豆汁儿) – an acquired taste, aromatic and sour, it’s distinctly Beijing 

Ordering ease: Buy a queue ticket before entering. Menus may lack English, but staff are patient, and pointing/photo menus work well 

Cash & Card: Payment doesn’t require advanced prep; just bring cash or cards.

Title: Hongbinlou Restaurant 鸿宾楼饭庄 (展览馆路)
Description:
🍽️ Hongbinlou Restaurant 鸿宾楼饭庄 (展览馆路)

📍 Address: No. 11 Zhanlanguan Road (展览馆路11号), Xicheng District, Beijing — near Chegongzhuang West (Line 6)  

🕒 Opening Hours:
• Lunch: 11:00 AM–2:00 PM
• Dinner: 5:00 PM–8:30 PM (closes at 10 PM on weekends) 

💳 Cost: Around ¥150–210 per person 

🌟 Heritage & Cuisine
Founded in 1853 in Tianjin and relocated to Beijing in 1955 at Premier Zhou Enlai’s invitation—renowned as Beijing’s “First Muslim Restaurant” and one of the original “Beijing Eight Great Lou” 

Features halal Tianjin-Muslim cuisine, including full-lamb banquet craftsmanship listed as national intangible heritage 

Menu blends Tianjin halal specialties with Beijing dishes—roast duck, lamb, seafood, soups, and stir-fries 

🍲 Must-Try Dishes
Dish	Description
Red‑braised oxtail (红烧牛尾)	Signature—tender, saucy, and rich; praised as “absolutely superb” 
“Yuan Bao” Fried Chicken (芫爆散丹)	Fragrant peppery dish, expertly balanced 
Clay‑pot lamb head (砂锅羊头)	Unique, hearty local favorite 
Squirrel Mandarin Fish (松鼠桂鱼)	Crispy-sweet classic stir-fry 
Sweet "San Bu Zhan" dessert & sugar scrolls (糖卷果)	Traditional treats rounding out the meal 

🏛 Ambience & Experience
Interior features high ceilings, carved wood furnishings, and a stately banquet hall—ideal for celebrations and gatherings 

Recognized for formal yet welcoming service, making it a popular venue for family events and business meals 

Decor reflects a blend of traditional Muslim and Northern Chinese aesthetics 

📝 Visitor Tips
Go early for popular dinner items—prime dishes can sell out 

Group-friendly: Choose a variety of signature dishes to share and fully experience the menu

Halal standards: All meats and preparation follow strict halal requirements

Getting there: Near Chegongzhuang West (Line 6); paid parking available

Language: English menus are limited; pointing and translation apps work—staff are accustomed to tourists

Payment: Accepts cash and credit cards 

🎯 Why Overseas Visitors Should Go
Historic dining landmark: A living piece of Beijing’s 170‑year-old culinary history

Culinary excellence with a story: From full‑lamb banquets to heritage soups

Rich setting: Impressive atmosphere ideal for photography and cultural immersion

Authentic halal dining: A top-tier, internationally recognized experience in Muslim‑style Northern cuisine
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours:
• Lunch: 11:00 AM–2:00 PM
• Dinner: 5:00 PM–8:30 PM (closes at 10 PM on weekends) 

Go early for popular dinner items—prime dishes can sell out 

Group-friendly: Choose a variety of signature dishes to share and fully experience the menu

Halal standards: All meats and preparation follow strict halal requirements

Getting there: Near Chegongzhuang West (Line 6); paid parking available

Language: English menus are limited; pointing and translation apps work—staff are accustomed to tourists

Payment: Accepts cash and credit cards

Title: Tai Feng Lou Restaurant (泰丰楼饭庄) – Qianmen Branch
Description:
📍 Address: No. 2 Qianmen West Street, Xicheng District, Beijing (formerly on Meishi Street; one of Beijing’s historic “Eight Great Lou” of old coal-market street) 

🕒 Opening Hours: Daily around 11:00 AM–2:00 PM lunch (some branches open longer) 

🍽 Cuisine: Classic Shandong-style (Lu cuisine) with authentic Beijing flair — especially “soup” based dishes and hearty stir-fries 

🌟 Highlights & Signature Dishes
Hui Wuyu Egg Soup (烩乌鱼蛋汤): Shandong specialty—light, savory fish roe in clear broth 

Sour & Spicy Chicken-Shredded Soup (酸辣鸡丝汤): A beloved tummy-soother directed at finishing meals—refreshing and slightly tart 

Dry-fried Turbot Fish (干炆多宝鱼): Robustly sauced yet tender, with crisp accents like garlic and bamboo shoots 

Crispy Duck (香酥鸭): A nod to Peking duck—golden-crisp exterior, succulent interior, served with pancakes, condiments and sugar-dip 

Others: Wok-fried shrimp, flash-fried pork tripe, peppery beef strips, trio-sauté, three-flavor meatballs—each spotlighting traditional Lu techniques 

🏛 Historical & Cultural Context
Founded 1876 by Sun family from Haiyin, Shandong, as one of Beijing’s earliest “Eight Great Lou” establishments 

Continues original cooking methods: hand-stirred, pan-seared, and daily-simmered artisanal broths from chicken and pork knuckles 

Esteemed by Q&A: once praised by Qing-era diarist Chong Yi for its enduring quality, and frequented by notable political figures 

📝 Dining Tips for Overseas Guests
Arrive early at opening to avoid crowds—especially for lunch, as some signature items sell out quickly 

Order a few dishes to share—a balanced mix of soup, fish, crispy duck, and stir-fries showcases the breadth of Lu cuisine

Don’t skip the soups—the restaurant prides itself on soup-making ("the soul of the kitchen") and these warm, flavorful bowls anchor the meal 

Savory-dinner vibe: modestly decorated with traditional wood interiors, intimate feel, friendly service from seasoned waitstaff 

Price Range: Typically ¥100–160 per person, moderate and value-driven 

🎯 Why It’s Ideal for Overseas Visitors
A taste of heritage: With nearly 150 years of history, Tai Feng Lou offers a genuine snapshot of Beijing’s culinary and social legacy

Classic yet approachable: Dishes are flavorful without being overwhelming for foreign palates

Authentic ambiance: The restaurant’s traditional décor and time-honored style reflect old Beijing’s soul

Easy access: Located in the bustling Qianmen area—perfect for combining sightseeing with a satisfying meal
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: Daily around 11:00 AM–2:00 PM lunch (some branches open longer) 

Arrive early at opening to avoid crowds—especially for lunch, as some signature items sell out quickly 

Order a few dishes to share—a balanced mix of soup, fish, crispy duck, and stir-fries showcases the breadth of Lu cuisine

Don’t skip the soups—the restaurant prides itself on soup-making ("the soul of the kitchen") and these warm, flavorful bowls anchor the meal 

Savory-dinner vibe: modestly decorated with traditional wood interiors, intimate feel, friendly service from seasoned waitstaff 

Price Range: Typically ¥100–160 per person, moderate and value-driven

Title: Tongheju Restaurant (同和居饭庄) – Yuetan, Xicheng District
Description:
🏮 Tongheju Restaurant (同和居饭庄) – Yuetan, Xicheng District

📍 Address: No. 71 Yuetan South Street (月坛南街甲71号), Xicheng District, Beijing 

🕒 Opening Hours: Daily
Lunch: 10:00–14:00
Dinner: 16:30–21:30 

🌟 Highlights & Signature Features
Rich history & heritage: Established in 1822 during the Qing dynasty, Tongheju is the oldest and most prestigious of Beijing’s “Eight Great Ju” restaurants, with a plaque inscribed by Emperor Puyi’s brother, Pu Jie 

Culinary excellence: Famous for classic Shandong cuisine and Beijing specialties—don’t miss dishes like braised cuttlefish roe in spicy-sour sauce, preserved cod, “San Bu Zhan” egg-yolk pudding, scallion-braised sea cucumber, and sweet-sour fish fillets 

Elegant atmosphere: Features traditional courtyard and wooden interiors, antique decorations and private rooms, evoking Old Beijing charm 

Michelin Bib Gourmand: Recognized for maintaining authentic, high-quality cuisine at good value 

📝 Dining Tips for Overseas Visitors
Arrive early to avoid busy lunch and dinner crowds—especially during weekends and Chinese holidays.

Group-friendly portions: Shareable dishes are encouraged—try a mix of seafood, meat, and dessert specialties.

English support: Menus may have limited English; pointing to photos works well. Staff are helpful and accustomed to international guests.

Ideal for photos: The blend of cultural décor and stunning dishes makes for memorable Instagram-worthy moments.

💵 Price Range
≈ ¥115–150 per person, with high-value dishes shared among diners 

🎯 Why It’s Perfect for Travelers
Tongheju offers a captivating blend of history, culture, and culinary craftsmanship. It’s an immersive opportunity to savor Beijing’s gastronomic and architectural heritage through impeccable Shandong-style dishes—served in a storied setting that truly stands out for both food and atmosphere.
Tips:
📍 Address: No. 71 Yuetan South Street (月坛南街甲71号), Xicheng District, Beijing 

🕒 Opening Hours: Daily
Lunch: 10:00–14:00   Dinner: 16:30–21:30 

Arrive early to avoid busy lunch and dinner crowds—especially during weekends and Chinese holidays.

Group-friendly portions: Shareable dishes are encouraged—try a mix of seafood, meat, and dessert specialties.

English support: Menus may have limited English; pointing to photos works well. Staff are helpful and accustomed to international guests.

Ideal for photos: The blend of cultural décor and stunning dishes makes for memorable Instagram-worthy moments.

💵 Price Range
≈ ¥115–150 per person, with high-value dishes shared among diners

Title: Qingyunlou Restaurant (庆云楼饭庄) – Shichahai Branch
Description:
📍 Address: Front Lake East Bank (前海东沿22号), near Silver Ingot Bridge, Shichahai, Xicheng District, Beijing 

🕒 Hours: Daily, typically 11:00 AM–9:30 PM 

🍽 Cuisine & Ambience
A historic Lu cuisine (Shandong-style) restaurant founded in 1820, one of Beijing’s original “Eight Great Lou” 

Built in traditional wooden, mortise‑and‑tenon style, the restaurant exudes an authentic Qing-era atmosphere—complete with courtyard-style architecture, antique woodwork, calligraphy, and carved screens 

Multiple floors: 1F offers signature Shandong dishes; 2F serves Vietnamese-style specialties; 3F features private rooms; 4F rooftop has a scenic terrace overlooking Shichahai and the Drum & Bell Towers 

🥢 Signature Dishes
Stewed sea cucumber with scallions, strained sweet‑sour fish fillets, Nine‑turn pork intestines, “San Bu Zhan” dessert 

Specialty roast duck, bean sprout salad, shrimp spring rolls, Vietnamese coconut beef hot pot 

“Hui‑character” patterned mung‑bean rolls, artisan snacks noted for decorative presentation 

🌟 Dining Tips for Visitors
Request a rooftop or lakeside seat—2F windows and 4F terrace offer lovely lakeside views, especially at sunset or during festivals 

Popular evening spot—arrive early or reserve for terrace seats; rooftop tables often incur a ~15% surcharge 

Try both cuisines—combine classic Shandong dishes on the 1st floor with fragrant Vietnamese-style options upstairs for a diverse experience 

Moderate pricing, hearty portions—average around ¥150–200 per person; dishes are generous and well‑valued 

Cultural ambience—marrying architecture, calligraphy, and design from Qing-era Beijing, it's a compelling stop for history and food lovers.

🎯 Why Overseas Guests Love It
Qingyunlou combines nearly 200 years of Beijing culinary heritage, a memorable historic setting, and lakeside views in central hutong in one immersive dining experience. 

Its blend of traditional Lu cuisine and Vietnamese surprises ensures a rich, flavorful introduction to Beijing’s evolving food culture.
Tips:
🕒 Hours: Daily, typically 11:00 AM–9:30 PM 

Request a rooftop or lakeside seat—2F windows and 4F terrace offer lovely lakeside views, especially at sunset or during festivals 

Popular evening spot—arrive early or reserve for terrace seats; rooftop tables often incur a ~15% surcharge 

Try both cuisines—combine classic Shandong dishes on the 1st floor with fragrant Vietnamese-style options upstairs for a diverse experience 

Moderate pricing, hearty portions—average around ¥150–200 per person; dishes are generous and well‑valued 

Cultural ambience—marrying architecture, calligraphy, and design from Qing-era Beijing, it's a compelling stop for history and food lovers.

Title: Tiantan Fuyan （天坛福宴）
Description:
📍 Address: Temple of Heaven West Gate +300 m on the left side (East City, Beijing) 

🕒 Opening Hours: 11:00 AM–2:00 PM & 5:00 PM–9:00 PM daily 

🍽 Cuisine: Beijing cuisine inspired by palace dishes—classic “palace-style snacks” and modern interpretations in a courtly setting 

🎯 What's Special
A national five‑diamond “garden” restaurant located steps away from the Temple of Heaven; praised as a popular “foodie destination” and cultural experience spot 

Decor echoes Temple of Heaven architecture—high ceilings, wooden screens, lanterns—perfect for atmospheric photos and a sense of ancient grandeur 

Menu balances traditional Beijing dishes (crispy roast duck, braised lamb), palace-style dim sum, and soups/afternoon tea sweets, served with poetic names and seasonal flair 

🍽 Recommended Dishes
Crispy Roast Duck with sugar dipping — "酥不腻" crispy yet not greasy 
Grilled lamb (炙子烤羊肉) — fragrant and tender 
Sesame‑sauce sweet pancake & Temple‑shaped mooncake desserts—perfect for tea-time treats 
"Fu" character dessert cups and plum-flower sweets—Instagram‑worthy and palate-pleasing 

💡 Dining Tips
No reservation needed, yet weekday midday is less crowded; weekends sell out—plan around your Temple visit 

Full‑meal experience: diners usually stay 2–4 hours; take time to explore the Palace‑style décor along with your meal 

Afternoon tea lovers: Arrive late morning or mid‑afternoon to catch the snack‑and‑tea service; sweets like sugar‑cakes are popular

Photo note: Dishes and interiors are picturesque—best lighting around 12–1 PM

Payment & facilities: Accepts credit cards, offers free Wi-Fi, has private tables and parking 

🎯 Why It’s a Must for Overseas Visitors

Combining a visit to the Temple of Heaven with lunch or afternoon tea at Tiantan Fuyan ensures a seamless blend of cultural sightseeing, historical ambience, and Beijing culinary heritage—all in one convenient location. With palace-style touches and beautifully presented dishes, it is both an enriching ...
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: 11:00 AM–2:00 PM & 5:00 PM–9:00 PM daily 

No reservation needed, yet weekday midday is less crowded; weekends sell out—plan around your Temple visit 

Full‑meal experience: diners usually stay 2–4 hours; take time to explore the Palace‑style décor along with your meal 

Afternoon tea lovers: Arrive late morning or mid‑afternoon to catch the snack‑and‑tea service; sweets like sugar‑cakes are popular

Photo note: Dishes and interiors are picturesque—best lighting around 12–1 PM

Payment & facilities: Accepts credit cards, offers free Wi-Fi, has private tables and parking

Title: Song Banquet “宋宴” – Immersive Song Dynasty Banquet in Beijing
Description:
📍 Address: Near Exit A, Beitucheng Station (Lines 8 & 10), Beichen Road, Chaoyang District, Beijing 

🕒 Hours: Daily 10:30 AM–2:00 PM & 5:30 PM–9:00 PM 

🍽 Cuisine: Creative Chinese fusion influenced by Song Dynasty court-style dishes—elegant, poetic, and theatrical.

✨ What Makes It Special
Immersive time travel: Staff dressed in Hanfu introduce you to Song-era rituals—tea pouring, flute/music, dancing—while you dine 

Artful presentations: Each dish is served like a chapter of a poem—expect “Baoyu Dongpo Pork,” Hulu Soup, Lion’s Head meatballs, West Lake shrimp cakes, Osmanthus yam pudding, and Ice-cream goose liver 

Performance-driven ambiance: On-floor performances in the main hall, while upstairs private rooms feature rotating mini-shows, holographic Song-verse recitations, and classical décor 

🍛 Notable Dishes
Lion’s Head Meatball: Rich broth; melts in your mouth 

Baoyu Dongpo Pork with Abalone: Tender, sweet-savory, and soul-satisfying 

West Lake Shrimp Cake & Steamers: Delicately crisp and fresh 

Hulu Soup & Osmanthus Yam Pudding: Seasonal, aromatic, light palate cleansers 

📝 Tips for Visitors
No formal reservations for main hall; first-come, first-serve for six seats. Private rooms require booking in advance 

Arrive early around opening to secure a spot and perhaps enjoy a special “birthday Song Banquet” experience with full ritual and decoration 

Cultural fun included: Play traditional games—tossing arrows, chinese shuttlecock. Staff assist in garment change for photos and enhance immersion 

Parking available; located right at subway exit A for easy access 

🎯 Why Song Banquet Is a Must for Overseas Guests
This is not just dining—it’s an experiential journey into Song Dynasty elegance, perfectly blending arts, poetry, cuisine, attire, and performance. Whether you're celebrating a birthday or seeking a cultural spectacle, Song Banquet offers:

A vivid, immersive atmosphere that transports you a thousand years back

A menu that balances ceremonial richness with refined fusion

Highly “Instagrammable” settings, performances, and thoughtful tableware

A memorable performance-dining combo that resonates long after the meal
Tips:
📍 Address: Near Exit A, Beitucheng Station (Lines 8 & 10), Beichen Road, Chaoyang District, Beijing 

🕒 Hours: Daily 10:30 AM–2:00 PM & 5:30 PM–9:00 PM 

Immersive time travel: Staff dressed in Hanfu introduce you to Song-era rituals—tea pouring, flute/music, dancing—while you dine 

No formal reservations for main hall; first-come, first-serve for six seats. Private rooms require booking in advance 

Arrive early around opening to secure a spot and perhaps enjoy a special “birthday Song Banquet” experience with full ritual and decoration 

Cultural fun included: Play traditional games—tossing arrows, chinese shuttlecock. Staff assist in garment change for photos and enhance immersion

Title: Tianchu Miaoxiang Vegetarian Restaurant / 天厨妙香素食餐厅
Description:
🌿 Tianchu Miaoxiang Vegetarian Restaurant / 天厨妙香素食餐厅

📍 Address: 2F, Bldg D, Chaowai SOHO, 6B Chaoyangmenwai Dajie, Chaoyang District, Beijing (near Guanghua Bridge) 

🕒 Opening Hours: Daily, 10:00 AM–9:30 PM (Chaoyang branch) 

🍽 Cuisine: Pure Buddhist-style vegetarian (no eggs, alcohol, garlic, or allium roots)—creative mock-meat dishes, tofu, mushrooms, salads, plus vegetarian pizza & pasta 

🌟 Highlights & Signature Dishes
Kung Pao Monkey-Head Mushroom (宫保翠珍): a Bib Gourmand staple—spicy, tangy, and deeply satisfying 

“Vegan fish”: king oyster mushrooms in teriyaki-style sauce, mimicking taste and texture of eel 

Mock-meat sausage (“随缘解馋”): praised for “fibrous texture and meaty flavor” 

Chestnut tofu clay pot & flaming tofu: popular local favorites 

Fresh veggie bowls & pineapple tofu dessert: lighter, refreshing options 

💡 Why Visitors Love It
Bib Gourmand recognized for combining quality ingredients, value, and creativity 

Cozy, peaceful atmosphere with Buddhist-inspired décor and garden vibes—great for a relaxed meal 

Huge menu (~100 dishes) with photos and English descriptions, appealing to vegetarians and curious meat-eaters alike 

Widely recommended by travelers on Tripadvisor & HappyCow: “Really good food and portions,” “insanely good vegan food,” “menu with big pictures and English” 

📝 Tips for Overseas Visitors
No reservations — walk-in only; weekdays & lunchtime are quieter 

Staff speak limited English—menus feature English names & photos for easy ordering 

Ideal for sharing: order 2–3 dishes per couple; generous portions

Try vegetarian pizza or pasta for a twist

If visiting the Tsinghua branch, check it out for its open kitchen and occasional cooking workshops 

💵 Average Spend
Approximately ¥70–85 per person, great value given the quality and experience 

🎯 Final Take
Tianchu Miaoxiang is a top-tier vegetarian destination in Beijing's CBD—melding Buddhist purity with bold flavors, inventive dishes, and an airy, soothing setting. It’s easy to recommend for travelers seeking health-conscious variety, English-friendly menus, and a relaxed dining experience all in one.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: Daily, 10:00 AM–9:30 PM (Chaoyang branch) 
No reservations — walk-in only; weekdays & lunchtime are quieter 

Staff speak limited English—menus feature English names & photos for easy ordering 

Ideal for sharing: order 2–3 dishes per couple; generous portions

Try vegetarian pizza or pasta for a twist

💵Approximately ¥70–85 per person, great value given the quality and experience

Title: Gong De Lin Vegetarian Restaurant / 功德林素菜饭庄
Description:
🌿 Gong De Lin Vegetarian Restaurant / 功德林素菜饭庄

📍 Address: 2 Qianmen East Street, Dongcheng District, Beijing
🕒 Opening Hours: Daily, 10:30 AM–9:00 PM 
🍽 Cuisine: Buddhist-style vegetarian Chinese—expertly crafted mimic-meat dishes using tofu, mushrooms, and vegetables

🌟 Highlights & Signature Dishes
"Braised pork belly" made from winter melon and monkey-head mushrooms; sweet‑sour "fish" crafted from king oyster mushrooms and tofu 

Silken pineapple dessert, shrimp-style balls, and mock chicken feet—all visually deceiving and delicious 

Recognized by the Michelin Guide (Bib Gourmand) for quality and value 

💡 Dining Tips
No reservation needed—just walk in; private rooms are available upstairs for small groups 

Choose “recommended items” on the English/Chinese menu to enjoy the chef’s specialties 

Portion sizes are generous—ideal for sharing among 2–4 people 

Drinks menu only in Chinese, but tea, beer, and soft drinks are available 

Facilities & accessibility: Air-conditioned, wheelchair-accessible, credit cards accepted 

Average spend: ~¥80 per person—excellent value for Beijing standards 

🎯 Why It's Perfect for Overseas Visitors
Gong De Lin offers a rare taste of Buddhist vegetarian artistry in Beijing—dishes that look and taste like meat, yet are completely plant-based. With its historic legacy since 1922, central location just south of the Forbidden City, and English-friendly menus, it’s a delightful cultural and culinary experience. Enjoy innovative flavors, friendly service, and a peaceful ambiance—all at very good value.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: Daily, 10:30 AM–9:00 PM 
No reservation needed—just walk in; private rooms are available upstairs for small groups 
Choose “recommended items” on the English/Chinese menu to enjoy the chef’s specialties 
Portion sizes are generous—ideal for sharing among 2–4 people 
Drinks menu only in Chinese, but tea, beer, and soft drinks are available 
Facilities & accessibility: Air-conditioned, wheelchair-accessible, credit cards accepted 
Average spend: ~¥80 per person—excellent value for Beijing standards

Title: Siji Minfu Roast Duck (四季民福烤鸭店)
Description:
🕒 Opening Hours: Daily, 10:30 AM–10:30 PM 

🍽 Cuisine: Traditional Beijing-style roast duck and northern Chinese classics

🌟 Highlights & Signature Dishes
Peking Duck: Known for ultra-crispy skin with thin, tender slices—served table-side, often dipped with sugar or hoisin 

Complimentary hawthorn jelly offered at the end to refresh the palate 

Homestyle Northern dishes: "bean sprout salad," "Belair grilled meat" (mildly spiced lamb), stir-fried pea shoots, duck soup, and signature “Dumpling basket” sides 

📝 Dining Tips
Go early—arrive at opening to avoid long waits. Popular branches often see lines within 30 minutes 

No reservation needed—tickets taken for queue; highly recommended to go before peak lunch/dinner 

Order half a duck if dining solo or in small groups; menu in English with helpful visuals 

Try sugar-dipped skin—a local favorite, unique to Siji Minfu’s presentation 

Complement with sides: stir-fried peas or mushroom dishes are light and refreshing sides to cut richness.

💵 Price Range
Half duck: ~¥108–159
Full duck: ~¥259–299
Most dishes: ¥20–100
Average spend: ¥120–180 per person 

🛋 Ambience & Vibe
Traditional Chinese decor: dark wood, lanterns, waterscape features, and a calm yet vibrant interior 

Welcomes both locals and foreigners; more relaxed and less frenetic than tourist-heavy chains 

🎯 Why It’s Perfect for Overseas Visitors
High-quality duck without the Quanjude crowd: Crispier skin, warm service, and more tranquil vibe 

English-friendly: Bilingual menus make ordering straightforward; staff assist with wrapping and sauce.

Cultural authenticity: Experience the classic Beijing roast duck tradition in a local yet comfortable setting.

Good value: Excellent flavors and atmosphere without premium prices.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: Daily, 10:30 AM–10:30 PM 
Go early—arrive at opening to avoid long waits. Popular branches often see lines within 30 minutes 
Order half a duck if dining solo or in small groups; menu in English with helpful visuals 
Average spend: ¥120–180 per person 
Welcomes both locals and foreigners; more relaxed and less frenetic than tourist-heavy chains

Title: Si Shi Tong Tang (四世同堂)
Description:
📍 Address: For example, Shuangjing branch – 1F, Tower A, Raffles City (Fuli Twin Towers), No. 59 East 3rd Ring Middle Road, Chaoyang, Beijing. Near Shuangjing subway station (Line 10 & 7). 

Other branches: Xibianmen, Chegongzhuang, Deyang etc.

🕒 Opening Hours:
Typically 10:30 AM–9:30 PM daily; some branches extend to late night or operate 24/7 

🍽 Cuisine: Classic and creative Beijing-style (Jingcai) with Imperial flair—Peking duck, traditional cold appetizers, Clay Pot dishes, and theatrical presentation.

🌟 Highlights & Signature Dishes
Guàlú Roasted Duck (挂炉烤鸭): Crispy skin, juicy meat—served theatrically on a traditional gong-drum (“luogu”); symbolizing festivity and nostalgia 

Da Chi Bao “Zhuo Wu Kui” (大赤包捉五魁): Creative Mahjong‑shaped pea custard inspired by Lao She’s novel—delightfully sweet and Instagram-worthy 

Qianlong Cabbage (乾隆白菜): A classic cold dish flavored with sesame paste, vinegar, sugar, mustard—crisp and refreshing 

Other favorites include Porcelain Pot Pork, Spicy Intestines, Three‑Item Stir‑Fry, Sān Bù Zhān dessert, and shrimp sauté. 

🏛 Ambience & Experience
Immersive Old-Beijing décor: Grey bricks, carved wood, retro signage, lanterns, traditional props, and costumed staff evoke a 1940s Beijing scene—as if stepping into Lao She’s novel 

Multiple themed private rooms: Around 23 rooms styled after characters from Four Generations Under One Roof. Upstairs for groups, downstairs for casual dining 

Cultural performances: Some branches host evening traditional music, Peking opera excerpts, or drum performances adding to the nostalgic atmosphere 

📝 Dining Tips
Reservation recommended on weekends or for private rooms; call ahead 

Arrive early to enjoy evening performances and get good seating 

Share dishes with family/friends—menu designed for communal dining.

Capture the moment: Dish presentations and décor are very photo-friendly—ideal for social media.

English menu & basic support: Staff trained to guide tourists; menu may include English or rely on visuals.

💵 Price Range
Approximately RMB 120–180 per person, depending on dishes and beverages—great value considering the experience 

🎯 Why It's Perfect for Overseas Visitors
Si Shi Tong Tang offers more than a meal—it’s an immersive cultural journey through old Beijing, blending literature, history, flavors, and performance. Diners savor traditional Beijing cuisine in a nostalgic setting that truly brings Four Generations Under One Roof to life.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours:
Typically 10:30 AM–9:30 PM daily; some branches extend to late night or operate 24/7 

Guàlú Roasted Duck (挂炉烤鸭): Crispy skin, juicy meat—served theatrically on a traditional gong-drum (“luogu”); symbolizing festivity and nostalgia 

Arrive early to enjoy evening performances and get good seating 

Share dishes with family/friends—menu designed for communal dining.

English menu & basic support: Staff trained to guide tourists; menu may include English or rely on visuals.

Approximately RMB 120–180 per person, depending on dishes and beverages—great value considering the experience

Title: Niujie Halal Man Heng Ji / 牛街清真满恒记
Description:
🕌 Niujie Halal Man Heng Ji / 牛街清真满恒记

📍 Address: No. 14 Ping’anli West Street (corner of Zhaodengyu Rd), Xicheng District, 

🕒 Opening Hours: 11:00 AM–11:00 PM (no reservations for main hall; private room needs one-week notice) 

🍽 Cuisine: Halal Beijing-style charcoal shuanrou (instant-boiled mutton hotpot) with Mongolian Sunite lamb and Shandong beef 

⭐ Highlights & Signature Dishes
Hand‑cut lamb slices, tender and mild—with customizable fat-to-lean ratio. Prized for being lean and gamy-free 

Classic sesame flatbreads (shaobing), served freshly baked—crispy with rich peanut-sesame flavor 

White broth lamb spine hotpot: slow-cooked for depth, served with spicy chili oil and sesame-garlic dip 

Also available: Marinated beef tripe (bao du), five-spice mutton, lamb skewers, homemade sweet sesame buns 

💡 Dining Tips
Use e‑queue apps (e.g. "Mei Wei Bu Yong Deng") to skip long waits—especially dinner time is peak 

Order mixes or half‑portions: ideal for sampling lamb, beef, tripe and other sides without waste 

Customize dipping sauce: base sesame-garlic sauce blends perfectly with chili oil and cilantro

Expect authentic ambience: smoky, aromatic with sizzling charcoal in open layout – may carry a distinctive “offal” smell though it adds to the charm 

Group-friendly & budget‑wise: vibrant and communal, ~¥85–110 per person depending on choice 

🎖 Recognition
Michelin Guide “Bib Gourmand” pick in Beijing for offering high-quality local fare at reasonable prices 

🎯 Why Overseas Visitors Should Go
Nestled in the heart of Niujie—Beijing’s Muslim Quarter—Man Heng Ji provides an immersive experience into Beijing’s halal hotpot culture, served over roaring charcoal in a rustic, lively setting. It’s a must-visit for travelers seeking bold taste, cultural authenticity, and that iconic sesame flatbread ritual.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: 11:00 AM–11:00 PM (no reservations for main hall; private room needs one-week notice) 
Group-friendly & budget‑wise: vibrant and communal, ~¥85–110 per person depending on choice

Title: Ya’er Li Ji (鸦儿李记)
Description:
🍲 Ya’er Li Ji (鸦儿李记) – Authentic Beijing-style Copper-Pot Hot Pot & Snacks

📍 Main Locations:
Houhai / Shichahai: No. 19 Ya’er Hutong, Xicheng, near Yinding Bridge
Others: Hepingli West, Zhanlan Road, Tiantan, Gulou area (multiple branches)

🕒 Opening Hours: Generally 11 AM–9:30 PM; select locations (e.g., Guijie flagship) open 24/7 

🍽 Cuisine: Halal Beijing-style copper-pot hot pot (shuanrou) and traditional snacks

🌟 Highlights & Signature Items
Copper-pot hot pot (涮肉) with hand-cut lamb leg and beef slices — tender, fresh, and served in a classic clear broth over charcoal 

Beijing-style breakfast & snacks: sesame flatbreads (shaobing), fried dough cakes, soy milk, mantou, marinated beef, lamb skewers, tripe, yoghurt, glutinous rice balls (tangyuan)—locally famous and nostalgic 

Stir-fried geda (northern-style dough lumps) served with veggies & meat—an underrated local classic 

💡 Dining Tips
Arrive early for snacks like sesame flatbreads—they sell out quickly and are priced at around ¥1 each 

Queue smart: flag down staff when busy, or join the digital queue if available 

Customizable spice & broth: request mild (clear broth) or richer sesame dipping; broth base is mild to let the meat shine 

Shareable feast: Ideal for groups—order hot pot and a spread of snack plates to taste a little of everything

Payment & language: WeChat/Alipay accepted; basic English menu may be available, but pointing at dishes works fine

🎯 Why Overseas Visitors Should Go
Cultural immersion – Ya’er Li Ji blends Beijing’s historic hutong charm with vibrant street-snack culture.

Authentic flavors – Tried-and-true favorites like hand-cut lamb hot pot and sesame flatbreads offer a deliciously local experience.

All-day appeal – From breakfast snacks to late-night hot pot, it fits any adventurous eater’s schedule.

Budget-friendly – Excellent value at roughly ¥100–150 per person 

Locals love it – Multiple local recommendations and positive tips on Reddit and travel sites attest to its authenticity 

📝 Sample Intro for Overseas Guests:
Ya’er Li Ji is an unmissable slice of old-Beijing life—set in atmospheric hutongs, serving everything from sesame flatbreads at breakfast to chili-flecked copper-pot hot pot late into the night. Order hand-cut lamb or beef for your hot pot, then layer your tray with traditional snacks and stir-fried geda. Arrive early or queue up smartly—you might find yourself directed by nods and hand-points in true zhajiang style!
Tips:
📍 Main Locations:
Houhai / Shichahai: No. 19 Ya’er Hutong, Xicheng, near Yinding Bridge
Others: Hepingli West, Zhanlan Road, Tiantan, Gulou area (multiple branches)

🕒 Opening Hours: Generally 11 AM–9:30 PM; select locations (e.g., Guijie flagship) open 24/7 

Budget-friendly – Excellent value at roughly ¥100–150 per person 

Locals love it – Multiple local recommendations and positive tips on Reddit and travel sites attest to its authenticity

Title: Hu Da Restaurant (胡大饭馆 / Huda Restaurant)
Description:
📍 Address: 233 Dongzhimen Inner Street (Guijie), Dongcheng District, Beijing
🕒 Opening Hours: 24/7 at main Guijie location; others typically 11 AM–2 AM 

🍽 Cuisine: Sichuan-style spicy Chinese, famous for crayfish and hot & numbing flavors 

🌟 Highlights & Signature Dishes
Spicy & Garlic Crayfish (麻辣/蒜蓉小龙虾): Juicy, plump offerings so popular they sell out fast—expertly shelled for you upon request 

Spicy Pig Trotter, Chongqing Chicken, Mapo Tofu, Skewers, Hot & Sour Soup: A wide selection for group sharing 

Vibrant Guijie ambiance: A buzzing late-night street filled with lights, locals, expats, and energy 

📝 Tips for Overseas Visitors
Expect queues: It's one of Beijing’s most popular crayfish spots—waiting 1–3 hours isn't uncommon. Use QR “queue online” options or arrive before 5 PM 

Handy service: Staff can help shell crayfish for you—ideal if you're not used to eating with your hands 

Choose your spice: Options range from mild garlic to full-on mala; tell them your preferred heat level 

Cash or card? All locations accept cards and WeChat Pay; smaller branches may be cash-friendlier.

Large groups? Private rooms available and turnovers are fast—call ahead or show up early.

🎯 Why It's a Must for Travelers
Hu Da is more than a restaurant—it’s a living part of Beijing’s nightlife culture. A 1999 startup by Anhui native Sun Yuzhen, she pioneered the spicy crayfish trend on 

It blends traditional Red Capital energy with authentic Sichuan flavors—perfect for adventurous eaters craving a bold, communal, and late-night feast.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: 24/7 at main Guijie location; others typically 11 AM–2 AM 
Expect queues: It's one of Beijing’s most popular crayfish spots—waiting 1–3 hours isn't uncommon. Use QR “queue online” options or arrive before 5 PM 

Handy service: Staff can help shell crayfish for you—ideal if you're not used to eating with your hands 

Choose your spice: Options range from mild garlic to full-on mala; tell them your preferred heat level 

Cash or card? All locations accept cards and WeChat Pay; smaller branches may be cash-friendlier.

Large groups? Private rooms available and turnovers are fast—call ahead or show up early.

Title: Qi Xun Ba Zhao (七寻八找) – Hutong Cuisine Hidden Gem
Description:
🍜 Qi Xun Ba Zhao (七寻八找) – Hutong Cuisine Hidden Gem

📍 Address: Xi‑lou Hutong, Hutong 2nd Alley A1, near Yonghe Temple, Dongcheng District, Beijing

🕒 Opening Hours:
Mon–Fri: 11 AM–2 PM & 5 PM–9:30 PM
Sat–Sun: 11 AM–3:30 PM & 5 PM–9:30 PM 

🍽 Cuisine: Beijing-style hutong dishes with creative twists

⭐ Highlights & Signature Dishes
Xiao Guan “Ji Li Beng” (鸡里蹦) – Crisp-fried shrimp & chicken bits in a tangy-sweet sauce; a must-try 

Clay pot grilled bass (炭烧味鲈鱼) – Crispy exterior, tender inside; very popular among locals 

Thick gravy rice (浓汁泡饭) – Hearty rice soaked in rich broth, often with seafood or quail egg; described as “令人惊艳” by visitors 

Almond tofu (杏仁豆腐) – Light and refreshing; perfect palate cleanser after savory dishes 

Creative cold dishes: strawberry with bitter herbs, tofu rolls, “guozi” buns, etc. 

🏡 Ambiance & Experience
Nestled deep in a hutong, the entrance is easy to miss—true to its name, “seek seven, search eight” 

Decor features traditional grey brick walls, red lanterns, nostalgic hutong vibes; small upstairs dining area offers more cozy seating 

Pretty packed at peak lunch/dinner times—arrive early or during off-peak for easier seating 

💡 Tips for Travelers
Follow the map carefully—you’ll have to walk down a narrow alley about 20 m to find the door.

Share dishes among 2–4 people: portion sizes are moderate, and it's fun to try a variety.

Start early—especially if you want the xiao-guan chicken and grilled fish, which sell out fast 

Bring cash or WeChat Pay, although QR code payment is usually available.

Approx. cost: ¥60–100 per person, very reasonable 

🌟 Why It's Ideal for Overseas Visitors
Qi Xun Ba Zhao captures Beijing’s authentic hutong spirit—not just in flavors, but in hidden location, nostalgic décor, and friendly local service. It’s a unique culinary adventure for travelers eager to explore beyond tourist hotspots—innovative traditional dishes served in a setting full of character and history.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours:
Mon–Fri: 11 AM–2 PM & 5 PM–9:30 PM
Sat–Sun: 11 AM–3:30 PM & 5 PM–9:30 PM 
🍽 Cuisine: Beijing-style hutong dishes with creative twists
Nestled deep in a hutong, the entrance is easy to miss—true to its name, “seek seven, search eight” 
Pretty packed at peak lunch/dinner times—arrive early or during off-peak for easier seating 
Share dishes among 2–4 people: portion sizes are moderate, and it's fun to try a variety.
Bring cash or WeChat Pay, although QR code payment is usually available.
Approx. cost: ¥60–100 per person, very reasonable

Title: Casserole Pot Restaurant (砂锅居饭庄)
Description:
🍲 Casserole Pot Restaurant (砂锅居饭庄)

📍 Address: No. 60 Xisi South Street, Xicheng District, Beijing – near Xisi South 大街 

🕒 Opening Hours: Daily, 11:00 AM–9:30 PM 
(Historically a half-day operation, now full-day service since the mid-20th century) 

🍽 Cuisine: Historic Beijing-style hot pot and Manchu-influenced “sandy-pot” (clay-pot) dishes, part of the traditional “Eight Great [Ju] Restaurants” of old Beijing 

💡 Highlights & Signature Dishes:
Clay-Pot Boiled Pork with Pickled Cabbage ('砂锅白肉'): Thin slices of pork, tangy sauerkraut, and glass noodles served in a bubbling sandy-pot — the signature item since 1741 

‘Sān bù zhān’ (三不沾): A legendary sweet‑sticky dessert—“doesn’t stick to plate, chopsticks or teeth” that locals rave about 

‘Jiǔ zhuǎn dà cháng’ (九转肥肠): Flavorful pork intestines braised to perfection 

‘Bào sāng yàng’ & ‘Bào sān yàng’ (爆三样): A delicious stir-fry of pork slices, intestines, and liver that bursts with flavor 

Other favorites: ‘Dry-fried meatballs’, ‘tofu-stuffed clay pot’, ‘almond tofu’, and ‘crispy baked buns’ are local go-tos 

🍽 Dining Tips:
Arrive early: The white pork sells out quickly—just like old Beijing days when they said “sales over by noon” 

Share dishes: Order a mix of clay-pot specialties, stir-fries, and desserts to sample the full range of flavors.

Atmosphere: Rustic, stately décor—an old-state run restaurant with a heritage vibe. Popular with locals, so full at peak hours 

Transport & seating: A short walk from Xisi; some parking; multiple floors with private rooms available 

Budget: Mid-range, around ¥100–120 per person 

Foreigner-friendly: Menus can include English or pictures, although staff may not speak fluent English.

🎯 Why Overseas Visitors Should Try It:
Casserole Pot Restaurant is a living relic of Beijing’s culinary and cultural heritage. As one of a handful of restaurants dating back to the Qing dynasty (founded 1741), it offers a genuine taste of traditional Beijing–Manchu comfort food in a historic setting. The flavors are bold, the dishes communal, and the tradition behind each sandy-pot makes every meal both delicious and memorable.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: Daily, 11:00 AM–9:30 PM 
(Historically a half-day operation, now full-day service since the mid-20th century) 

🍽 Cuisine: Historic Beijing-style hot pot and Manchu-influenced “sandy-pot” (clay-pot) dishes, part of the traditional “Eight Great [Ju] Restaurants” of old Beijing 

Arrive early: The white pork sells out quickly—just like old Beijing days when they said “sales over by noon” 

Transport & seating: A short walk from Xisi; some parking; multiple floors with private rooms available 

Budget: Mid-range, around ¥100–120 per person 

Foreigner-friendly: Menus can include English or pictures, although staff may not speak fluent English.

Title: Fu Hua Zhai Pastry Shop / 富华斋饽饽铺 (护国寺新天地店)
Description:
🍡 Fu Hua Zhai Pastry Shop / 富华斋饽饽铺 (护国寺新天地店)

📍 Address: No. 85 Huguosi Street, Huguo Temple New World, Xicheng District, Beijing

🕒 Opening Hours: Daily, ~9 AM–9 PM 

🍽 Cuisine: Traditional Manchu‑style imperial pastries, handmade following Qing‑dynasty palace recipes 

💡 Highlights & Signature Treats:
Imperial craftsmanship: Founded by Wang Xifu (grandson of a Qing imperial chef), using ancient rolling and layering techniques to produce flaky, refined pastries 

Popular delicacies:
Rose bean paste crisp (玫瑰豆蓉酥) – delicate, mildly sweet with real rose essence 
Almond tofu – smooth, fragrant, light dessert perfect as a palette cleanser 
Yundoujuan (芸豆卷) – soft bean rolls filled with hawthorn, sesame & osmanthus 
NaiLao GuoZi Bing (奶酪果子冰) – fermented-rice cheese dessert with fruits, cool and refreshing 
Rolling donkey (驴打滚), gua ren oil crisp, peanut cakes, among ~27 classic items 

📝 Tips for Overseas Visitors:
Café or takeaway: Seating is limited (traditional kang-style and small tables); takeaway orders are quick, with service calling when ready 

Afternoon delight: Popular around tea-time; lines can reach 30–60 minutes during weekends/afternoons 

Shareable snacks: Perfect for tasting flights—order several varieties (usually ¥8–28 each) and pair with tea.

Cultural experience: Step into a mini Forbidden-City vibe with red lacquer décor, regal plates, and traditional music 
hoppy foodie

Average spend: Around ¥55–70 per person 

English-friendly: Visual displays help ordering; staff are used to tourists and can assist.

✨ Why It’s Worth Visiting:
Fu Hua Zhai revives authentic palace-era desserts in a charming, culturally immersive setting. It's ideal for international travelers looking to explore Beijing’s sweet heritage through gallery-worthy pastries, royal ambiance, and hand-crafted quality.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: Daily, ~9 AM–9 PM 

🍽 Cuisine: Traditional Manchu‑style imperial pastries, handmade following Qing‑dynasty palace recipes 

Cultural experience: Step into a mini Forbidden-City vibe with red lacquer décor, regal plates, and traditional music 
hoppy foodie

Average spend: Around ¥55–70 per person 

English-friendly: Visual displays help ordering; staff are used to tourists and can assist.

Title: Fengze Yuan Restaurant / 丰泽园饭店
Description:
📍 Address: No. 83 Zhushikou West Street, Xicheng District, Beijing (near Meishi Jie/Kou)
🕒 Opening Hours:
Lunch: 11 AM–2 PM   Dinner: 5 PM–8:30 PM 
🍽 Cuisine: Classic Shandong (鲁菜) with Beijing/Huaiyang accents; also serves Peking Duck 

🍲 Highlights & Signature Dishes
Braised Sea Cucumber with Scallion (葱烧海参): A legendary dish made famous at Fengze Yuan and beloved worldwide 

“One Fish Four Ways” & Fish Maw Soup: Diverse preparations highlighting freshness 

Other specialties: Sweet‑fried apples, deep‑fried tripe patties, Crystal Pork Tendon, shark’s fin, roasted duck, nine‑turn large intestine, steamed pig elbow, and fried meatballs 

Ambience: Lavish courtyard-style interior, multiple private banquet halls and rooms for 600+ guests 

💡 Dining Tips for Overseas Visitors
Ideal for groups & banquets: Extensive seating and private rooms make it perfect for families or business dinners.

Go early: Lunch and dinner fill quickly, especially on weekends.

Try a variety: Start with seafood and cold appetizers, then move to hearty mains like sea cucumber, fish preparations, and Peking duck.

Take-home treat: Red‑bean steamed buns are a beloved souvenir 

Getting there: Short walk from Zhushikou (or Ping’anli) metro; parking available 

Budget: Mid-to-upper range, around ¥180–214 per person depending on dishes and drinks 

English support: Staff may have basic English; larger branches (e.g., Wangfujing) tend to be more foreigner-friendly 

🎯 Why Visit?

Fengze Yuan is a heritage staple with over 90 years of history as one of Beijing’s “Eight Great Restaurants.” It provides a grand, authentic introduction to northern China’s culinary arts—rooted in Shandong, refined in Beijing, and elevated with luxurious temple-style decor. A must-experience for international guests wanting a taste of China’s time-honored bibimbap.
Tips:
📍 Address: No. 83 Zhushikou West Street, Xicheng District, Beijing (near Meishi Jie/Kou)
🕒 Opening Hours:
Lunch: 11 AM–2 PM   Dinner: 5 PM–8:30 PM 
🍽 Cuisine: Classic Shandong (鲁菜) with Beijing/Huaiyang accents; also serves Peking Duck 
Go early: Lunch and dinner fill quickly, especially on weekends.
English support: Staff may have basic English; larger branches (e.g., Wangfujing) tend to be more foreigner-friendly

Title: Zhimeizhai Restaurant / 致美斋饭庄
Description:
🌟 Zhimeizhai Restaurant / 致美斋饭庄

📍 Address: No. 35 Baiguang Road (near No.66 Middle School), Xicheng District, Beijing

🕒 Opening Hours: Daily 10:30 AM–2 PM, 5 PM–9 PM 

🍽 Cuisine: Traditional Beijing/Shandong cuisine with historical “gongting” (imperial court) influence 

🍲 Highlights & Signature Dishes
“One Fish Four Ways” (四吃活鱼): A chef’s specialty served in four distinct styles—braised head & tail, sweet‑sour cube, sauced mid‑section, and fermented rice‑wine fish fillet 

Other classic dishes: Salt‑fried tripe patties, lotus seed fritters, sweet‑fried apples, red‑bean steam buns, “Bao‑san‑yang” meat trio, and crab‑egg fish 

Imperial roots: Founded in 1808 on nearby Meishi‑Street, it became a gourmet venue for Qing elites; now revived by the Xiongda Group with restored traditional recipes 

📝 Dining Tips
Space & reservation: Multiple floors including private banquet rooms—book ahead for family gatherings or group dinners.

What to order: Start with cold appetizers, then explore “one fish four ways” and specialty entrees for a full experience.

Takeaway treat: Their soft red‑bean buns are popular to bring home 

Access: Located ~5 min walk from Ping’anli Station (Lines 4 & 6); street parking may be limited 

Average spend: Mid‑range, ~¥56–97 per person depending on dishes 

English‑friendly: Menus often translated; staff at major locations are accustomed to foreign guests.

🌿 Why Overseas Guests Love It
Zhimeizhai offers a deep dive into Beijing’s culinary heritage—melding imperial-era flavors with regional Shandong and halal traditions. Its central location, flavorful yet approachable dishes, and culturally rich story arc make it a compelling choice for travelers seeking authentic local cuisine.
Tips:
Space & reservation: Multiple floors including private banquet rooms—book ahead for family gatherings or group dinners.

What to order: Start with cold appetizers, then explore “one fish four ways” and specialty entrees for a full experience.

Takeaway treat: Their soft red‑bean buns are popular to bring home 

Access: Located ~5 min walk from Ping’anli Station (Lines 4 & 6); street parking may be limited 

Average spend: Mid‑range, ~¥56–97 per person depending on dishes 

English‑friendly: Menus often translated; staff at major locations are accustomed to foreign guests.

Title: Liuquanju Restaurant / 柳泉居饭庄
Description:
🕒 Opening Hours: Daily, ~10:30 AM–9:00 PM 

🍽 Cuisine: Traditional Beijing and Shandong dishes, with strong influence from royal‑style cooking (“gongting cai”) and halal variations 

💡 Highlights & Signature Dishes
Historical legacy: Founded in 1567, originally a renowned Beijing yellow‑wine tavern by a willow tree and sweet spring, later evolving into one of Beijing’s famed old‑time “eight great restaurants” 

Culinary techniques: Skilled in stir‑frying, deep‑frying, braising, and stewing—melding bold Beijing flavors with Shandong and Hui (halal) cooking styles 

Don’t‑miss dishes: “Bao‑San‑Yang” trio, golden crab with salted egg yolk, deep‑fried shrimp segments, crispy lotus seed fritters, sweet‑fried apples, scallion‑braised sea cucumber, “zha‑liudu” fish slices, and classic dou sha bao red‑bean buns 

Cultural importance: Beijing-style cooking techniques listed as non‑material cultural heritage 

🎯 Why Overseas Visitors Should Go
Liuquanju provides a rare glimpse into centuries‑old Beijing culinary traditions—serving time‑honored recipes in a historic setting that's easy to access and enjoyable for international guests. With English-translated menus, friendly service, and iconic Beijing‑style dishes, it’s a perfect introduction to authentic local flavors.
Tips:
Group-friendly: Spacious venue with multiple floors and several private/hotpot rooms—great for family or group dining 

Order variety: For best taste, try a mix of cold and hot dishes: start with cold trays, then move to stir‑fried and specialty items like sea cucumber or “bao‑san‑yang”.

Bean‑bun takeaway: The hot dou sha bao (red‑bean buns) are fresh and popular—consider taking some home.

Service & ambience: Friendly, well‑trained staff; restaurant can get lively and noisy around peak times.

Transport convenience: Just a ~2‑minute walk from Ping’anli Station (Lines 4 & 6). Paid parking available across the street 

Mid‑range budget: Around ¥140 per person on average

Title: 🇮🇹 Bottega 意库 (Sanlitun, Chaoyang)
Description:
📍 Address: 1F, Jinshang Building, 20 Xinyuan Xi Li West, Chaoyang, Beijing

🕒 Opening Hours: Daily, around 11 AM–12 AM 
🍽 Cuisine: Authentic Neapolitan-style Italian fare—pizza, pasta, salads, and more 
Gambero Rosso International

💡 Highlights:
Award-winning Neapolitan pizzas—ranked among Asia's top pizzerias, with chewy, light crusts and high-quality mozzarella 

Popular dishes: Quattro pizza (16″ with four flavors), Primavera pizza (bresaola, asparagus), burrata, pappardelle Bolognese, steak salad, and crispy “Yiku fries” 

Stylish, spacious interior with modern Italian design—family-friendly with kids’ highchairs and drawing materials 


📝 Dining Tips:

Reserve ahead, especially at peak dinner times—weekends can fill up fast.

Perfect for sharing: pizzas and pastas are designed for group enjoyment.

Visit on weekday evenings or for an early lunch to enjoy a more relaxed atmosphere.

Lots of English menus and attentive bilingual staff.

💰 Price Range:
Approx. ¥100–160 per person—considered great value for award‑winning authenticity.

✨ Why it’s ideal for overseas visitors:
Bottega 意库 brings an authentic taste of Naples to Beijing’s Sanlitun, offering high‑quality ingredients, an English‑friendly environment, and a fun, shareable dining experience. With international awards, stylish décor, and welcoming staff, it’s a top pick for pizza lovers and Italian cuisine seekers.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: Daily, around 11 AM–12 AM 
🍽 Cuisine: Authentic Neapolitan-style Italian fare—pizza, pasta, salads, and more 
Gambero Rosso International
Reserve ahead, especially at peak dinner times—weekends can fill up fast.
Perfect for sharing: pizzas and pastas are designed for group enjoyment.
Visit on weekday evenings or for an early lunch to enjoy a more relaxed atmosphere.
Lots of English menus and attentive bilingual staff.

Approx. ¥100–160 per person—considered great value for award‑winning authenticity.

Title: 🇯🇵 Manyo Yakiniku（万葉日式烧肉 - 后海店）
Description:
📍 Address: No. 17 Xifu Shouli, Houhai Hutong, Beihai North Station, Xicheng District, Beijing
🕒 Opening Hours: Evening service only, generally 17:00–23:00; weekend lunch also available (check local listings) 

🍽 Cuisine: Premium charcoal-grilled Japanese yakiniku featuring A5-grade and dry-aged wagyu beef

💡 Highlights:
Intimate setting with just six private tatami-style rooms, ideal for quiet, refined dinners 

Handpicked A5 marbled wagyu from Australia & the US, aged with precision and grilled over traditional Binchotan charcoal 

Signature dishes: thick-cut premium beef tongue, “extreme three-marrow” beef, bone-in short ribs, squid-ink sausage, and crab meat rice ✨

Special seasonal offerings like snowflake wagyu ribeye served with sukiyaki-style egg dip 

Japanese sake, shochu, whisky, and exclusive “Four-Leaf” sake selections available

📝 Dining Tips:
🔥 Grilling is an art — the staff can skillfully grill your meats, ensuring perfect doneness; follow their lead
Start light: Begin with milder items like beef tongue, then move on to richer cuts
Order crab rice— one of the best-loved items, infused with fresh crab sweetness
Private rooms make it perfect for date-nights or small groups — weekend and holiday slots fill quickly, so reserve ahead
Smoke-free: advanced below-table smoke extraction keeps clothes and hair fresh 

Why Overseas Guests Love It

Hidden in a peaceful hutong behind Beihai, Manyo transports you in both taste and ambiance — authentic Japanese charcoal grilling in a refined, intimate space.

Staff speak English and assist with grilling, helping diners relax and enjoy the experience.

The combination of top-tier wagyu, seasonal specialty dishes, and minimalist Japanese-style décor makes this a memorable culinary journey in Beijing.
Tips:
🕒 Opening Hours: Evening service only, generally 17:00–23:00; weekend lunch also available (check local listings) 
🍽 Cuisine: Premium charcoal-grilled Japanese yakiniku featuring A5-grade and dry-aged wagyu beef
🔥 Grilling is an art — the staff can skillfully grill your meats, ensuring perfect doneness; follow their lead
Start light: Begin with milder items like beef tongue, then move on to richer cuts
Order crab rice— one of the best-loved items, infused with fresh crab sweetness
Private rooms make it perfect for date-nights or small groups — weekend and holiday slots fill quickly, so reserve ahead
Smoke-free: advanced below-table smoke extraction keeps clothes and hair fresh

Title: 🇩🇪 Brotzeit 博璨德国啤酒餐厅 / Brotzeit German Bier Bar & Restaurant
Description:
🇩🇪 Brotzeit 博璨德国啤酒餐厅 / Brotzeit German Bier Bar & Restaurant

📍 Address: Grand Summit, Liangmaqiao, Chaoyang, Beijing – Floor 1 South Block (F109) 

🕒 Hours: Daily, approximately 11 AM–10 PM (weekday lunch specials around ¥88–¥100) 

🍽 Cuisine: Bavarian-style German beer hall

💡 Highlights:

Draft German beers imported under the Reinheitsgebot (Beer Purity Law), including Paulaner lagers and weissbiers 

Bavarian staples: crispy Schweinshaxe (pork knuckle), various wurst sausages (Nürnberger, Weisswurst), schnitzel, spaetzle, pretzels & apple strudel 

Casual, family-friendly vibe with long wooden benches, sports on TV, and a spacious patio 

📝 Dining Tips:

Lunch specials (~¥88): weekdays offer great value—try cordon bleu, meatballs, or smoked salmon with rösti 

Weekend evenings: busy—arrive early or reserve for group tables

Family-friendly: kids love the schnitzel and cheese spaetzle

Seating: window-side or patio spots are nice when weather permits; outdoor diners note service may be slower 

✨ Why You’ll Love It:
Brotzeit brings authentic Bavarian hospitality to Beijing. It's perfect for travelers craving big flavors, hearty food, and cold beer in a relaxed setting. Ideal for post-sightseeing dinners or group outings.
Tips:
🕒 Hours: Daily, approximately 11 AM–10 PM
Lunch specials (~¥88): weekdays offer great value—try cordon bleu, meatballs, or smoked salmon with rösti 

Weekend evenings: busy—arrive early or reserve for group tables

Family-friendly: kids love the schnitzel and cheese spaetzle

Seating: window-side or patio spots are nice when weather permits; outdoor diners note service may be slower

Title: 🇪🇸 CRAZYONES (克芮旺斯西班牙餐厅)
Description:
✨ Why it's a great pick for overseas visitors:
CRAZYONES offers a true taste of Spain in Beijing—vibrant décor, diverse menu, and share‑style dining make it easy and fun for international guests. English-friendly staff and menus help with ordering, while the warm and artful interior enhances the experience.

Title: Desert Rose Turkish Restaurant / 沙漠玫瑰
Description:

🕒 Hours: Daily, 9 AM–12 AM
🍽 Cuisine: Turkish / Middle Eastern
💡 Highlights:
Authentic Turkish plates: kebabs, mezze, pide
A favorite among expats; genuine décor & ambiance
English menus and bilingual staff
📝 Tips: Good for breakfast or late-night snacks; ask for “special bread” suggestion.
Tips:
📍 Address: 39 Shenlu Street, Chaoyangmenwai, Beijing

Title: Model Bookstore + Poetry Space (模范书局·诗空间)
Description:
📚 Model Bookstore + Poetry Space (模范书局·诗空间) – A Century‑Old Church Turned Literary Sanctuary
Nestled at No. 85 Tonglinge Road, this stunning bookstore resides within a 1907 Anglican Church, making it China’s only bookstore in a church and one of Beijing’s “ten most beautiful bookstores” 

🏛️ What Makes It Magical
Architectural fusion: Retains soaring vaulted ceilings, Gothic-inspired stained glass, octagonal skylight pavilion, and period wood floors—yncredible blend of East–West and historic power 

Vaulted reading hall: Towering shelves line a central nave where the original baptismal font is now a reading stage—a poetic centerpiece 

Antique printing atelier: A dedicated area features carved woodblocks and traditional bookbinding tools, open for interactive demonstrations 

Curated selections: Focuses on literature, art, history, humanities, and especially poetry—over 3,000 poetry volumes with select rare editions showcased under glass 

👥 Who Will Love It
📖 Literature lovers & poetry enthusiasts—for the serene stacks and rare editions
🎨 Architecture & design buffs—drawn to the atmospheric church-turned-bookspace
🛋️ Slow‑travel travelers & urban retreat seekers—perfect for a quiet pause off the tourist radar
🧱 Cultural creatives—who’ll appreciate the tactile bookbinding demos and antique tools

🧭 Top Visitor Tips
⏰ Hours: Open daily 10:00–19:30, free entry 
🕑 Suggested visit: Spend 1–2 hours to explore the nave, mezzanine, printing area, and café nook 
📍 Getting there: Subway Line 2 → Xuanwumen, Exit A1 → 5‑minute walk 
📷 Photo tip: Use a wide-angle lens to capture the full nave—especially with sunlight filtering through stained glass.
